Investors turn OW Asia credit: best values in BBB corps, most OW Korea, cut duration (Published 18 August 2025)

Investors turn OW Asia credit at net \(11\%\) in Aug survey, vs net UW \(27\%\) in April. The survey was conducted over the period of 1- 11 Aug 2025. Credit spreads have been tightening on strong technicals and easing trade tensions over the past few months. In terms of spread expectations, the majority of investors expect spreads to remain unchanged \((75\% /72\% /63\%\) for 3mo/6mo/12mo period). In our view, technicals and fundamentals would remain solid to support the valuation, but further compression potential is limited. We expect Asia credit spreads to stay around the tight- end of our YE target (80bp for IG and 300bp for HY), under our base case of no rate cuts for the rest of 2025.
Investors add positions in both IG & HY corps from neutral/net UW \(44\%\) in Apr'25 to net OW \(8\%\) /net OW \(14\%\) in Aug'25.

Top risks: geopolitical, higher rates, trade war. Geopolitical risks and higher interest rates are the top two risks with a weight of \(22\%\) each, rising from \(16\%\) and \(19\%\) in Apr survey, respectively. Our economist keeps the call of no Fed cut in '25 as the option value of waiting remains high, to avoid starting the cutting cycle before inflation peaks. Trade war is the third- highest risk at \(20\%\) , which was the top risk in Apr (34%). The US effective tariff peaked at \(32\%\) , but decreased to \(15.2\%\) now, according to BofA estimation. However, trade- related uncertainty remains across the globe.

Investors see best value in BBB corps; most OW Korea, most UW HK; cut duration; most OW industrial, net UW cash. Most countries saw positioning increase except for HK (a cut of \(2\%\) to net UW \(22\%\) ). Korea saw the biggest positioning increase (48%) and is the most OW at net \(24\%\) . China and Thailand have a net OW at \(8\%\) and \(2\%\) , but the rest are net UW. BBB remained the best- value trade, followed by NBFCs and sovereign. Investors see less value in A corps, which ranked as the third best value- trade in Apr, Chinese bank AT1 and IG LGFVs; but more value in BB/B corps and dim sum bond.

Hong Kong bank: we asked investors about the impact of weak HK commercial real estate on banks' 1H25 earnings. \(46\%\) of respondents expect moderately weaker credit profile but no rating implication. \(32\%\) expect manageable impact with credit profile roughly unchanged YoY. \(11\%\) expect substantial neg. impact and high NPL ratio; while the rest \(11\%\) expect improving fundamentals YoY due to recovery of property valuation.

Hong Kong property: Given the recent negative headlines on smaller HK developers, we asked investors their view on the sector. \(42\%\) of respondents are cautious on smaller developers but comfortable with IG developers. Given the attractive risk- reward, \(30\%\) investors are looking for opportunities among bonds of those smaller developers. \(17\%\) investors are more risk- reverse, staying away from the whole sector, while \(11\%\) do not have particular concern as they believe banks are expected to be supportive.
Refer to the full report of Asian Credit Survey: Investors turn OW Asia credit: best values in BBB corps, most OW Korea, cut duration 18 August 2025 including important disclosures
Joyce Liang +65 6678 0408
(Published 28 August 2025)

The CNH bond market has been fast growing in recent years, reaching RMB1.5tn as end of Jul'25. Outside sovereign bonds and PBoC bills, foreign financial issuers (FIs) and China LGFVs have been key drivers. Rising CNH issuance from foreign FIs is mainly driven by 1) the interest rate gap between the US and China; and 2) strong demand from mainland investors amid declining yields in China onshore market. China LGFVs, on the other hand, have been active in CNH market due to tightened onshore issuance. In the recent months, CNH bonds have become topical as we see more issuance from non- financial corps outside China LGFVs. YTD, RMB32bn CNH bonds have been issued by non- financial corps (ex- China LGFVs), up \(30\%\) YoY, given the relatively low funding cost and increasing demand. For CNH corp bond issued in YTD25, on average, the CNH coupon rate is 35bp/19bp lower than comparable USD/EUR bond yields. In addition, some companies issue CNH bonds to meet RMB funding needs, like HK developers with investments in China mainland. On the demand side, it has been strong, given the attractive pick- up of CNH bond over other currencies and relaxation of Southbound Bond Connect (expanding eligible investors to China NBFCs). On a hedged basis, CNH bonds are now providing 22bp/13bp/6bp yield pick- up over CNY/EUR/USD bonds. With RMB depreciation pressure easing, we expect robust southbound inflows to lead to further compression. Within CNH universe, we find 1) HK financial and property are most attractive, while Chinese banks are most expensive, 2) HK and Singapore quasi are more attractive than China SOEs, and 3) foreign issuers' CNH bonds are cheaper than China/HK issuers with similar rating/duration.

Onshore credit bonds saw RMB778bn net supply in Jul, higher than RMB411bn in Jun. Financial bond net supply hit a record high of RMB418bn, driven by strong net supply from bank capital and security companies; non- financial net supply also increased to RMB358bn (+42% MoM). SOEs saw RMB317bn net supply, out of which LGFVs saw RMB42bn net redemption, while non- LGFV SOEs saw RMB358bn net supply. POEs saw RMB41bn net supply mainly from AAA ones, vs. net redemption of RMB37bn in Jun.

The LTM default rate by amount was unchanged at \(0.1\%\) and eased to \(0.21\%\) by count. The SOE default rate remained at the lowest end. POE default rate by amount/count dropped from \(3.7\% /5.7\%\) as end of Jun'25 to \(3.2\% /5.0\%\) as end of Jul'25.

In July & MTD- Aug, onshore yields went up 10bp/8bp for IG/HY to \(2.0\% /2.1\%\) , given no more near- term policy boost. We saw divergence in the offshore market. While offshore HY yields declined 100bp to \(11\%\) , offshore IG yields rose by 4bp to \(4.7\%\) . On a currency- hedged basis, offshore IG/HY continued to offer RV vs. onshore, which is now 91bps/717bps for IG/HY. On average, yield pick- up for CNY over USD bond after hedging is \(- 1.0\%\) for SOEs, \(- 0.57\%\) for LGFVs, \(- 3.68\%\) for property, and \(- 0.46\%\) for financials.
Refer to the full report of China Onshore Credit Bond Monthly: More CNH issuance from non- financial corps outside China LGFVs 28 August 2025 including important disclosures
Rachna Jain +65 6678 2972

S&P upgrades India: Rating to BBB, T&C assessment to AS&P upgraded India's sovereign credit rating to BBB/Stable from BBB-/Positive on \(14^{\text{th}}\) August 2025. The agency also revised India's transfer & convertibility (T&C) risk assessment, which usually caps foreign currency rating of Indian companies, to 'A-' from 'BBB+'. The upgrade was supported by the country's economic resilience and sustained fiscal consolidation while maintaining strong infrastructure drive. The agency also weighed in India's conducive monetary policy in managing inflationary expectations.

S&P rates 75 out of 277 USD bonds listed on BBG with India as Country of Risk. Before the sovereign rating action, S&P had 56 bonds at BB+ (5), BBB- (38), BBB (2) or BBB+ (11) levels from 19 issuers at BB+ (3), BBB- (13), BBB (2) or BBB+ (1) level.

Following the sovereign upgrade, S&P also upgraded 5 issuers - NTPC Ltd (NTPCIN), Oil & Natural Gas Corp Ltd (ONGCIN), India Railway Finance Corp Ltd (INRCIN), Export- Import Bank of India (EXIMBK) and State Bank of India (SBIN) from BBB-/Positive to BBB/Stable given strategic importance and/or government linkages of the companies. The agency also upgraded HDFC Bank Ltd (HDFCB), ICICI Bank Ltd (ICICI) and Tata Capital Ltd (TATASON) to BBB/Stable from BBB-/Positive as the final ratings on these financial institutions are capped by the sovereign rating. S&P assesses standalone credit profile of HDFCB, ICICI and TATASON at 'a- ', 'a- ' and 'bbb+'.

Fundamental improvements, if any, will drive upgrade for following six companies with sovereign rating or T&C constraints removed after the recent sovereign upgrade: Reliance Industries (RILIN, BBB+/Stable), Bharti Airtel Ltd (BHARTI, BBB-/Positive), Adani Ports & Special Economic Zone Ltd (ADSEZ, BBB-/Positive), Adani International Container Terminal Pvt Ltd (ADINCO, BBB-/Positive), Adani Electricity Mumbai Ltd (ADANEM, BBB-/Stable) and Summit Digital Infrastructure Ltd (SUMDIG, BBB-/Stable).

Lastly, we don't see any imminent rating impact on following five companies as their credit assessment is unconstrained at current levels and driven by fundamentals: ABJA Investment Co Pte Ltd (TATAIN, BBB/Stable), TML Holdings Pte. Ltd (TTMTIN, BBB/Stable), Adani Renewable Energy RJ Ltd (ARENRJ, BB+/Stable), Muthoot Finance Ltd (MUTHIN, BB+/Stable) and Shriram Finance Ltd (SHFLIN, BB+/Stable).

India's upgrade is a much- awaited positive development. We note that both Moody's and Fitch still rate India at Baa3/BBB- and that's too with Stable Outlook. Hence, the composite rating of the sovereign and most of the upgraded bonds will still be BBB- . Notwithstanding, the Indian IG OAS tightened by another 13bps post the upgrade from already tight levels versus other BBB issuers within Asia.
Refer to the full report of Asia Pacific Credit Update: S&P upgraded India to BBB, select bonds followed; India IG OAS 13 bps tighter 15 August 2025 including important disclosures
Sirius Chan +852 3508 3100

Seeing more value in perps in HYSAN complexIn part, likely affected by negative headlines of weaker/smaller HK developers, HYSAN bonds (+12bp) have meaningfully underperformed other HK corp bonds (A/BBB: - 11bp/- 18bp, excluding CPREIT bonds) on a year- to- date basis. They also trade at the wider end of Asian BBB corp bonds. We do not expect Hysan to see any negative rating actions in the next 12 months. In our view, its ratings (Moody's: Baa2/stable & Fitch: BBB/stable) have already reflected its high leverage. We also believe its (1) leverage is on track to peak in '26, (2) IP portfolio's resilient performance, and (3) asset disposal plan in part can keep its ratings stable. We continue to prefer perps to bullet bonds in the HYSAN complex. We reiterate OW 4.85 perp (carry yield: 6.9%) / 7.2% perp (7.0% YTC, callable in Sep'30) on their attractive yields. We also maintain OW '27' / '29' / '35, trading c.40- 70bp behind HK A corp bonds.

Net leverage to be largely stable in '25 & '26 and...We believe Hysan's net debt/EBITDA (perps as debt) will hover around 13.5x- 14.5x in '25 & '26 (vs. 13.5/14.0x as of end- '24/1H25). Our forecast is based primarily on (1) HK\\$2.6bn EBITDA (+5% vs. '24), (2) HK\\$1.8bn/HK\\$1.3bn capex in '25/26 (vs. HK\\$1.9bn in '24) incurred mainly by the ongoing construction of its LG8, (3) HK\\$1.9bn interest expense & perp distribution (vs. HK\\$1.7bn in '24), (4) HK\\$1.1bn dividend (unchanged vs. '24), and (5) gradual sales of Bamboo Grove and VILLA LUCCA.

...remain on track to improve in '27We maintain our view that Hysan's net debt/EBITDA is on track to decline in '27. (1) Hysan's LG8 is set for completion in 2H26, which will expand its Lee Gardens leasable portfolio by approximately 30%. We thus think its EBITDA will increase decently and capex will drop significantly in '27. (2) We expect the performance of Hysan's existing investment properties in HK to remain stable thanks to its strong execution and their good locations. (3) Hysan has launched a HK\\$8bn capital recycling program spanning the next 5 years and will gradually sell its non- core assets, including VILLA LUCCA, the To Kwa Wan project and the 2 blocks of Bamboo Grove.

Closer look at HK\\$8bn capital recycling programHysan will use the disposal proceeds to first repay its debt. For VILLA LUCCA (60%- owned), we estimate its gross saleable resources to be HK\\$6- 7bn (HK\\$3.2bn of which were sold as of mid- Aug'25). With its project loan fully repaid as of end- 1H25, it should be able to upstream cash to Hysan's holdco starting from 2H25. For the 2 blocks of Bamboo Grove (100%- owned), we estimate its gross sales proceeds to be HK\\$3.8bn. Hysan sees scope for some transactions to take place in 4Q25. For the To Kwa Wan project (25%- owned), its pre- sales may be launched in 4Q25. With it having a HK\\$6.6bn project loan (on a 100% basis), we do not think it can upstream cash to Hysan's holdco in the near term.
Refer to the full report of Hysan Development (subsidiary issuer): Net leverage on track to peak in '26; closer look at asset disposal program 20 August 2025 including important disclosures

The Indian IG- rated financial institutions (FIs) reported stronger credit fundamentals in 1QFY26 (calendar- year 2Q25). The commercial banks continued to see slow loan growth - key driver of better capitalization. The asset- quality improved moderately with stable credit cost. NIM compression was significant for the Indian banking sector, but for the four banks with USD bonds outstanding, this did not affect their earnings. The three private banks, HDFCB, AXSBIN, and ICICI, reported better fundamentals than SBIN, the only PSB under our coverage. We find value in AT1 bonds from the private banks, with YTC/G- spread at c.5.6%/c.170bp. In terms of NBFIs, fundamentals of POWFIN and RECLIN remained solid with margin expansion seen in 1QFY26 and a higher loan growth. The asset quality has been improving.

Post the S&P upgrade (please see: S&P upgraded India to BBB, select bonds followed; India IG OAS 13 bps tighter), the Indian financial senior space saw about 5bp tightening. Currently, it is still a low- BBB rated sector, despite the S&P upgrade, with spread levels tighter than Thai, Philippine, and Indonesia bank senior bonds with ratings at BBB2 to BBB3. With stable outlooks, we think it is unlikely for Fitch and Moody's to follow S&P's upgrade in the near term. Thus, India senior valuations look expensive to us. We downgrade SBIN 5.125 29, ICICI'26/27 to UW. Further, given the small spread differentiation, we prefer short- dated over long- dated bonds, and like bonds issued from the POWFIN- RECLIN complex, which offers c.10bp risk premium vs. the banks. Thus, we upgrade POWFIN'27, 5.25/6.15 '28 and RECLIN'26/27 to OW from MW but downgrade the rest to MW.

The Indian IG- rated FIs reported improved their credit profile in 1QFY26 (calendar- year 2Q25) with a higher capitalization and stable asset quality. Given slow loan growth at only \(0.6\%\) QoQ, the capitalization continued to increase, with the average CET1/Tier- 1/CAR at \(14.2\% /15.1\% /17.3\%\) , up 69bp/57bp/66bp YoY, and up 21bp/23bp/36bp QoQ. Asset quality remained stable. The gross/net NPL ratio came in at \(1.6\% /0.5\%\) , as of end- Jun'25, up 4bp/6bp QoQ but down 14bp/2bp YoY. The coverage ratio slightly decreased by 2ppt YoY to \(79.4\%\) . In terms of profitability, banks saw YoY earnings growth of \(6.4\%\) in 1QFY26 with loan growth and non- interest income mitigating the margin pressure. The Indian NBFIs' Tier- 1/ capital- to- risk- weighted assets ratio (CRAR) came in at \(21.9\% /23.2\%\) on average for POWFIN /RECLIN, remained at a high level but 1.8ppt to 3.8ppt lower YoY, mainly due to higher loan growth at about \(13\%\) YoY. Asset quality continued to improve with gross and net NPL ratio at \(1.5\%\) and \(0.3\%\) , as of end- June'25, down 151bp/54bp YoY, respectively. In general, both companies performed better than the banks during the quarter.
Refer to the full report of Banks - India: 1QFY26 results solid but valuation looks expensive post rally on S&P upgrade 21 August 2025 including important disclosures
Rachna Jain +65 6678 2972

Sammaan Capital (IHLIN) issued USD300mn 8.95% 2028s secured bond on 21 Aug 2025 largely for onward lending. S&P Global Ratings' upgrade to B+/Stable from B/Positive in March 2025 and Moody's positive outlook on its B2 rating of the company in the same month adequately reflect IHLIN's improving business and financial profile against the backdrop of a conducive operating environment. However, IHLIN 28s is trading at g- spread of 533bps offering +90- 290bps pick- up against relevant peers - Indian NBFCs and renewables, and Macau gaming players. Hence, we add coverage of IHLIN 8.95 28s at Overweight on attractive valuation and some technical support from competitive domestic liquidity. We also maintain Overweight on IHLIN 27s, which tightened by 8bps post new issue but still trade at attractive g- spread of 493bps, on similar grounds.

Management is focusing on secured home loans and loans against property through its asset light strategy to grow AUM (guidance: INR1,000bn by end- FY27 from INR624bn, including INR235bn of legacy assets, at end- 1QFY26) amid supportive regulations. The legacy portfolio will reduce from 38% of AUM to single- digit contribution by FY27, per management. The asset quality is stable with GNPA/NNPA at 1.5%/0.8% at end- 1QFY26, largely flat QoQ, down from 2.7%/1.5% at end- 1QFY25. The NIMs 2%- 4% are weighed by lower yields of 10%- 11%. The rundown of legacy book and moderation of financing cost should support NIMs hereon. On credit cost front, management maintained its 100bps annual guidance with potential one- off gains to be used to create additional provisions. The company's high CAR of - 35% at end- FY25 (highest amongst the five NBFCs in our portfolio) post recent equity raise offers some buffer. For 1QFY26 results analysis, please see: 1QFY26: Growth AUM +33%; supportive regulations, Maintain OW.

The central bank's revised co- lending guidelines, announced earlier this month (effective Jan 2026), are supportive of management's growth plan. Key features of the new co- lending framework: 1) it expands beyond priority sector lending to non- priority segments as well, 2) can be adopted by all Indian financial institutions, 3) permits NBFC to NBFC co- lending also, and 4) allows minimum retention ratio of 10% instead of 20%.

S&P upgraded India's sovereign foreign currency credit rating to BBB/Stable from BBB- /Positive on \(14^{\text{th}}\) August 2025. Post the upgrade, Indian USD IG/HY OAS tightened by 12/16bps from already tight levels versus other BBB issuers. Consequently, the gap between USD bond yields swapped in INR and onshore INR bonds has reduced but it is still positive, per our estimates. We expect technical to remain supportive in general but select companies to tap dollar bond market amid growth aspirations for multitude of reasons - better pricing since March 2025, diversification, ticket size, duration, expensive/selective local bank financing (especially for certain NBFCs) and/or lower domestic appetite for asset- light models.
Refer to the full report of Sammaan Capital Ltd: Add coverage on IHLIN 8.95 28s at OW 22 August 2025 including important disclosures
Sirius Chan +852 3508- 3100

In our view, while Swire is a conglomerate, its credit profile is still driven primarily by the performance of its property business (i.e. Swire Prop). SWIRE bonds may be unable to offer significant diversification benefits to investors amid the slowdown in China's & HK's property markets. Swire's credit profile is weaker than Swire Prop's, with its EBITDA interest coverage/ net gearing/ net leverage at \(3.9x / 23\% /5.0x\) in 1H25 (vs. Swire Prop: \(4.6x / 16\% /4.9x\) ). Swire's rating (Moody's: A3) is also one notch below Swire Prop's (A2). We believe they will have a similar fundamental trend, with slightly higher/ stable net leverage in '25/ '26. In the HK A corp space, SWIPRO '28 trade at the wider end, c.20bp behind CKHH '28 (A2) & largely in line with WREICL '28 (A2). But SWIRE bonds trade at the tighter end, generally c.15- 30bp inside other similarly maturing HK A corp bonds. We thus see more value in SWIPRO bonds than SWIRE bonds. We reiterate OW SWIPRO '28 (z+102bp, 2.4 years to maturity). We downgrade SWIRE '30 (z+82bp, 4.4 years to maturity) to UW from MW and add coverage on '29 (z+73bp, 3.9 years to maturity) & '32 (z+104bp, 7.0 years to maturity) with UW given their tight valuation.

We believe Swire Prop's net debt/EBITDA as of end- '25 will be mildly higher than the level as of end- 1H25 (i.e. \(4.9x\) ). We draw comfort from its solid execution & high- quality investment property (IP) portfolio. We also think the ongoing construction of its IPs in China will be mitigated by its potential asset disposals, launch of The Headland Residences (a residential project in HK), and ramp- ups of its relatively new offices in HK (i.e. Two Taikoo Place/ Six Pacific Place which were completed in Sep'22/ Feb'24 and were \(68\% /56\%\) let as of end- 1H25). We expect Swire Prop's net leverage to be largely stable in '26 thanks in part to the completion of some of its new projects in China & its continuing asset recycling activities.

Swire has 3 core businesses, including property, beverages & aviation (mainly Cathay Pacific which is not consolidated into Swire). We think Swire's net leverage trend will be similar to Swire Prop's. \(61\% /75\%\) of its LTM 1H25 EBITDA/ end- '25 total assets were from Swire Prop. We expect Swire's beverages business to be largely stable, with its stronger performance in China more or less offset by weaker performance in other regions. In our view, the performance of Cathay Pacific may largely hold up despite the normalization of its passenger yield & uncertainties caused by tariffs & changes to the de minimis exemption in the US.
Refer to the full report of Swire Pacific Ltd. (subsidiary issuer): Post 1H25 results updates; prefer SWIPRO to SWIRE bonds 27 August 2025 including important disclosures
Rachna Jain +65 6678 2972

Muthoot Finance Ltd (MUTHIN) priced USD600mn 6.375% 2030s secured bond on 26 Aug 2025 largely for onward lending. Recent rating actions – Fitch's upgrade to BB+/Stable from BB/Stable last week, following Moody's upgrade to Ba1/Stable from Ba2/Stable in Apr 2025 and S&P's upgrade to BB+/Stable from BB/Stable in March 2025 – adequately reflect the company's strong credit profile, being the benchmark name as one of the largest gold loan lenders in India in a conducive operating environment. However, MUTHIN 30s is trading at ask g-spread of 263bps offering attractive pick-up against other BB+ USD bonds in Asia with similar maturity. MUTHIN 29s (ask g-spread: 236bps) is also attractive at current level post about 20bps of widening YTD against around 18bps of contraction in India HY space on an average over the period. We add coverage on MUTHIN 30s at Overweight and upgrade MUTHIN 29s to Overweight from Marketweight on attractive valuation and some technical support from competitive domestic liquidity. MUTHIN 28s are trading at the tighter end, but we maintain Marketweight given pick-up against Indian BB infrastructure peers and US BB names along with supportive technical.

MUTHIN reported \(37\% /10\%\) YoY/QoQ growth in its asset under management (AUM) in 1QFY26 to INR1,339bn (+40% gold loan book to INR1,132bn) coupled with 19bps YoY pick- up in NII to interest- generating assets ratio (11.3% vs. 11.1% in 1QFY25) – largely due to 52bps growth in yield to 18.1% while cost of borrowings (calculated on IBL) also decreased by 3bps to 8.8%. At consolidated level, management plans to limit non- gold loan book to 15- 20% of total AUM and maintain its interest spread in the region of 9.5%. MUTHIN's asset quality is improving with GNPA/NNPA at 2.6%/1.3% by end- 1QFY26 vs 4.0%/2.6% in 1QFY25 vs 3.4%/2.0% in 4QFY25. The group reported debt/tangible equity of 3.4x at end- 1QFY26 compared to 2.6x at end- 1QFY25. While CAR dropped to 22.0%, from 23.7% a quarter back and 27.5% a year ago, it remained well ahead of 15% regulatory requirement. For detailed 1QFY26 results analysis, please see: 1QFY26: Strong 3.7% AUM growth, better margins; Maintain MW.

S&P upgraded India's sovereign foreign currency credit rating to BBB/Stable from BBB- /Positive on 14th Aug 2025. Indian USD IG/HY OAS are still tight by 10/15bps since the upgrade, up from lows of 16/23bps on 18 Aug, from already tight levels vs other BBB issuers. Consequently, the gap between USD bond yields swapped in INR and onshore INR bonds has reduced but it is still positive, per our estimates. We expect technical to remain supportive in general but select companies to tap dollar bond market amid growth aspirations for multitude of reasons – better pricing since March 2025, duration, diversification, ticket size, expensive/selective local bank financing (especially for certain NBFCs) and/or lower domestic appetite for asset- light models.
Refer to the full report of Muthoot Finance Ltd.: Add MUTHIN 30s at OW, upgrade MUTHIN 29s to OW 27 August 2025 including important disclosures

On 27 Aug., OCBCSP issued a USD1bn tier- 2 bond, OCBCSP 4.55 2035 call in Sept'30 (OCBC'35), with a 10- year non- call 5- year structure. The bond was repriced at T+80bp with a yield of \(4.55\%\) . Although the Singapore tier- 2 space largely looks expensive with spread level at 50- 80bp, we still find the OCBC'35 attractive vs. peers on better relative valuation (RV) than peers, given 1) stronger fundamentals reported in 2Q25; and 2) the technical support should remain strong, in our view, on Singapore tier- 2. Thus, we add coverage on OCBCSP 4.55 2035 with Ow, similar to OCBCSP 5.52 2034.

Fundamental: stronger than peers based on 2QFY25 resultOCBCSP has consistently maintained a stronger credit profile than peers in recent years. Its CET1/tier- 1/CAR was \(17.0\% /17.8\% /19.6\%\) up 150- 170bp. Its CET1 ratio is similar to DBSSP but higher than UOB at \(15.3\%\) , and its tier- 1 and CAR were the highest among three banks. OCBCSP also has the best asset quality among peers with lowest NPL ratio at \(0.9\%\) at end'2QFY25 vs. peers at \(1.0 - 1.6\%\) . The provision at \(156\%\) looks sufficient and generally in line with peers. in terms of profitability, OCBCSP faces similar pressure in line with peers, and management cut the 2025 NIM target to \(1.90\% - 1.95\%\) (was \(2\%\) ). Despite margin compression of 12bp in 2Q25, the bank's NIM stabilized in June and it could see slight expansion in 3Q25, thanks to the deposit rate cuts that should lower funding costs. Further, the non- interest income grew \(5.4\%\) YoY in 2Q25 with wealth management business being the key driver. The strong fee income could partially mitigate the margin pressure (please see our equity report OCBC 2Q25 – slight beat; strong fees and AQ offset NIM pressure)

Strong technical support should continueThe capital bonds from Singapore banks have seen net redemptions in the past few years, with no additional tier- 1 capital bond outstanding now. As a frequent bond issuer, OCBCSP now has four tier- 2 bonds outstanding with one USD 1bn tier- 2 bond to be called on 10 Sept. Hence, the new tier- 2 could be well absorbed by the credit investors. Further, in 2024, the Singapore banks' capitalization was significantly boosted by the final Basel III implementation. The risk- weight asset decreased \(3.7\%\) YoY vs. loan growth in 2024. The much higher CET1 ratio reported at end June'25, as well as the need to control funding costs and protect margins, suggested low capital bond issuance need in the future. Please see our report on the capital ratio here: Banks - Singapore: 1H25 credit profile remains solid, but capital bonds appear expensive. Overall, we expect to see limited USD capital bond supply from Singapore banks from here.

We are OW AXSBIN 4.1 Perp on its attractive valuation vs. Indian HY perp bonds. It trades flat with big PSUs and ICICI in the short end, which means its smaller asset base offers no risk premium vs. the big and stronger banks.

The upside risks to our recommendations are 1) AXBIN has a significant fundamental improvement mainly leaded by the asset quality improvement, 2) it enjoys much stronger technical support if ICICI and PSUs deteriorated substantially, and 3) Indian economy further deliver positive surprise with stronger GDP, lower Inflation and surplus in fiscal account and current account.
The downside risk would be government's policy uncertainties to against the PSUs and the potential escalation of non- performing asset problems in India banking sector

We do not expect Hysan to see any further negative rating actions in the near term. We believe its high leverage is already factored into its ratings. Its fundamentals trend may be better than expected if it is willing to cut dividends and/or manages to sell non- core assets. We also view its liquidity as strong, given its good funding access. We are OW HYSAN '27/ '29/ '35 on their attractive relative valuation, trading at the wider end of Asian BBB- rated/ Hong Kong IG corp bonds. We are OW HYSAN 4.85% perp/ 7.2% perp on their attractive yields.
Downside risks are (1) substantial slowdown in Hong Kong's residential, office and/or retail market, (2) aggressive investments/ acquisitions, (3) aggressive dividend policy, (4)
significant increase in interest rates, and (5) weaker-than- expected funding access

Upside risks are (1) strong performance of Hong Kong's residential, office and/or retail market, (2) prudent investments/ acquisitions, (3) prudent dividend policy, (4) decline in interest rates, (5) strong funding access, and (6) asset sales

HDFC Bank Ltd (ticker: HDFCB) is the second largest commercial bank in India but the largest mortgage lender in the banking sector. We are also OW HDFCB'29, the most liquid senior bond win HDFCB complex, on its attractive valuation in the Indian senior bonds space, while we are MW HDFCB'26/27, on their tighter spread level vs. capital bonds. The upside risks to our recommendations are: 1) HFDCS keeps improving its capitalization but the Indian banks only have very little new bond issuance with both IG and HY issuance, and 2) the macro economy of India substantial improvement which resulted in credit rating upgrades. The downside risks to our recommendations are: 1) HDFCB's liquidity position continue to deteriorate which led to a meaningful concern on the bank in the capital market, 2) the company maintains aggressive loan growth which resulted in the lower capital ratio close to the write- off level at 6.125%.

ICICI is the largest private sector bank in India with market share of about \(5\%\) . It has been maintaining the strongest capitalization and highest retail clients which account roughly \(50\%\) of its loan book in the past few years. Its various subsidiaries have leading positions in different financial service sectors, such as asset management and insurance. While the bank has not issued any USD bond since 2017. We are UW ICICI 3.8% 27 / 4% 26 which looks expensive vs. Indian public sector bank peers. The upside risks to our recommendations are 1) ICICI enjoys much stronger technical support if PSUs deteriorated substantially and push the investor to privates banks, 2) Indian economy further deliver positive surprise with stronger GDP, lower Inflation and surplus in fiscal account and current account, and 3) a significant fundamental improvement mainly leaded by the asset quality improvement. The downside risks to the recommendations are 1) ICICI aggressive expands its non- commercial- banking business, which induces a weakening capital position, 2) the retail clients massively delay their payments on the obligation due to economic shock and 3) Sovereign risk rebounds and lead to a sovereign downgrade.
We are OW on MUTHIN 29s/30s on attractive valuation against Asian BB+ peers. We are MW MUTHIN 28s despite tighter valuation given pick- up against India BB infrastructure peers and US BB index.

Upside risks: (1) uptick in gold loan demand, and (2) rise in domestic gold prices. Downside risks: (1) significant and sustained decline in gold prices, and (2) adverse changes in regulatory guidelines relating to gold loan NBFC.

The bank generally has better fundamentals than peers on its high loss absorption buffers through cycle, superior asset quality, and great business diversification of Great East Holding, one of the largest insurance group in the region. We are OW OCBCSP 4.55 2035 and OCBCSP 5.52 2034 on their attractive valuation vs. OCBCSP 4.602 2032/1.832 2030 (MW). OCBCSP'32/30 is only fairly priced vs. DBSSP and UOBSP' tier- 2 bonds. The downside risks to our recommendations are: 1) commodity price volatility dampens the economy growth of Singapore and other ASEAN countries, 2) dramatic asset quality deterioration in Oil shore & Marine sector and housing sector amid economic slowdown, and 3) aggressive business expansion undermines capitalization and leads to more sub- debt supply. The upside risk to our recommendation is the business profile improves with extraordinary profit, which enhance the financial strengthen substantially.

Power Finance Corporation Ltd. (POWFIN) is an Indian Non- banking Financial Companies (NBFCs with total asset at about INR 7tn (USD 94bn). The company was incorporated in 1986 and was classified as an Infrastructure Finance Company (IFC) in 2010. The primary operation of POWFIN is conducting lending business to finance the power sector in India. Since 2007, POWFIN was a listed company in India domestic equity market (equity ticker of POWF IN). We are OW POWFIN 3.75 2027, 5.25 / 6.15 2028 on their attractive valuation relative to the commercial banks' long- dated paper, as well as the longer- dated POWFIN bonds, e.g. POWFIN 3.9 / 4.5 2029, 3.95 2030, 3.35 2031. We are MW those shorter- dated POWFIN bonds. The upside risk to our recommendations are 1) the company proactively manages to deleverage itself and has a substantial fundamental improvement in the coming years. 2) India sovereign credit rating remains to be stable at low BBB with outlook revised to stable or even positive, due to the better- than- expected Macro improvement. The downside risks are 1) being the policy tool of the Government of India, the company maintains fast loan growth which triggers the weakening credit rating downgrade. As a result, the senior bonds become to be fallen angels. 2) India sovereign credit rating downgrade results in a high yield rating of the senior bonds as well.

Rural Electrification Corporation Ltd. (RECLIN) is the key subsidiary of Power Finance Corporation Ltd. (POWFIN). In March'19, POWFIN finished the acquisition of RECLIN with a transaction of total INR 145bn (USD 2bn). Similar to POWFIN, RECLIN is a listed NBFC as well with the key focus on financial service for power sector largely in rural area. With RECLIN being the key subsidiary, the market share of POWFIN RECLIN complex is about \(50\%\) in India power financing sector. We are RECLIN OW 2.25 2026/3.875 27 on their attractive valuation vs. India commercial banks, but MW 2027RECLIN 4.625 2028/5.625 2028 and RECLIN 4.75 2029, as the valuation looks fair to us relative to the shorter- dated bonds. The upside risks to our recommendations of RECLIN is similar to POWFIN: 1) the company proactively manages to deleverage itself and has a substantial fundamental improvement in the coming years. 2) India sovereign credit rating upgraded due to the better- than- expected Macro improvement. The downside risks are 1) being the policy tool of the Government of India, the company maintains fast loan growth which triggers the weakening credit rating downgrade. As a result, the senior bonds become to be fallen angels. 2) India sovereign credit rating downgrade results in a high yield rating of the senior bonds as well.
We are OW IHLIN \(8.95\%\) 28s on favorable risk reward backed by robust capitalization and liquidity profile. We see the valuation as attractive compared to other Indian NBFC peers.

Upside risks: 1) better- than- expected collection and recovery of legacy book, 2) stronger- than- expected macro environment, 3) Faster- than- expected ramp up of asset light model disbursals, 4) significant improvement in profitability and funding channels, and 4) domestic real estate upcycle. Downside risks: 1) higher- than- expected losses from legacy book, 2) deteriorating collections and rising delinquencies, 3) adverse regulatory movements.

SBIN is the largest commercial bank in India with about one fifth market share. We like the systemic importance and general resilient financial matrix of SBIN relative to other PSUs, but the valuation is rich in EM and Asia. The merge of five small associate banks also poses moderate risk on its asset quality and capitalization. In past SBIN curve has traded in line with quasi- sovereigns, thus it is more like benchmark beta for sovereign risk than individual bank. Mainly due to the expensive valuation vs. Indian non- bank financial institutions (NBFCs), we are UW the SBIN 1.8 2026/2.49 2027/4.875 2028/5 2029/5.125 2029 on its expensive valuation vs. the POWFIN and RECLIN complex. The upside risks to our recommendations are 1) Indian economy further deliver positive surprise with stronger GDP, lower Inflation and surplus in fiscal account and current account, 2) a significant fundamental improvement mainly leaded by the asset quality and 3) government capital infusion is more meaningful than expected. The downside risks to the recommendations are 1) SBI merges other smaller PSUs which lead to a dilution to its capital base and surging of the NPL, 2) Government capital infusion postpones or cancelled due to a deteriorating fiscal balance, and 3) Sovereign risk rebounds and lead to a sovereign downgrade.

In our view, while Swire is a conglomerate, its credit profile is still driven primarily by the performance of its property business (i.e. Swire Prop). SWIRE bonds may be unable to offer significant diversification benefits to investors amid the slowdown in China's & HK's property markets. Swire's credit profile is weaker than Swire Prop's. Swire's rating is also one notch below Swire Prop's. We believe they will have a similar fundamental trend, with slightly higher/ stable net leverage in '25/ '26. In the HK A corp space, SWIRE bonds trade at the tighter end. We are UW SWIRE '25/ '29/ '30/ '32.

Downside risks to our recommendation: (1) a substantial slowdown in Hong Kong's property market which leads to a significant drop in Swire's recurring income, (2) its aggressive investments/ expansions, (3) meaningful increase in interest rates, and (4) weaker- than- expected funding access
Upside risks: (1) stronger- than- expected Hong Kong's property market, (2) prudent investments/ expansions, (3) meaningful decline in interest rates, and (4) strong funding access

Downside risks to our recommendation: (1) weak property markets in Hong Kong and/or China, (2) aggressive investments/ expansions, (3) meaningful increase in interest rates and (4) weaker- than- expected funding access.

In accordance with the SEBI (Foreign Portfolio Investors) Regulations, 2019 and with guidelines issued by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI), foreign investors (individuals as well as institutional) that wish to transact the common stock of Indian companies must have applied to, and have been approved as per SEBI (Foreign Portfolio Investors) Regulations, 2019. Each investor who proposes to transact common stock of Indian companies will be required to obtain Foreign Portfolio Investor (FPI) registration as per SEBI (Foreign Portfolio Investors) Regulations, 2019. Certain other entities are also entitled to transact common stock of Indian companies under the Indian laws relating to investment by foreigners. BofA Securities reserves the right to refuse to provide a copy of research on common stock of Indian companies to a person not resident in India. American Depositary Receipts (ADR) representing such common stock are not subject to these Indian law restrictions and may be transacted by investors in accordance with the applicable laws of the relevant jurisdiction. Global Depository Receipts (GDR) and the Global Depository Shares (GDS) of Indian companies, Indian limited liability corporations, have not been registered under the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and may only be transacted by persons in the United States who are Qualified Institutional Buyers (QIBs) within the meaning of Rule 144A under the Securities Act. Accordingly, no copy of any research report on Indian companies' GDRs or GDSs will be made available to persons who are not QIBs.

BofA Global Research provides recommendations on an issuer's bonds (including corporate and sovereign external debt securities), loans, capital securities, equity preferreds and CDS as described below. Convertible securities are not rated. An issuer level recommendation may also be provided for an issuer as explained below. BofA Global Research credit recommendations are assigned using a three-month time horizon.

Issuer Recommendations: If an issuer credit recommendation is provided, it is applicable to bonds and capital securities of the issuer except bonds and capital securities specifically referenced in the report with a different credit recommendation. Where there is no issuer credit recommendation, only individual bonds and capital securities with specific recommendations are covered. Loans, CDS and equity preferreds are rated separately and issuer recommendations do not apply to them.
BofA Global Research credit recommendations are assigned using a three-month time horizon:

Overweight: Spreads and/or excess returns are likely to outperform the relevant and comparable market over the next three months. Marketweight: Spreads and/or excess returns are likely to perform in-line with the relevant and comparable market over the next three months. Underweight: Spreads and/or excess returns are likely to underperform the relevant and comparable market over the next three months.
BofA Global Research uses the following rating system with respect to Credit Default Swaps (CDS):
Buy Protection: Buy CDS, therefore going short credit risk.

Sell Protection: Sell CDS, therefore going long credit risk.
